playn.core
Class AbstractLayer

java.lang.Object
  playn.core.AbstractLayer
All Implemented Interfaces:
Layer
Direct Known Subclasses:
LayerGL
public abstract class AbstractLayer
extends Object
implements Layer

Base Layer implementation shared among platforms (to avoid reinventing the transform logic).

Method Detail

destroy

public void destroy()
Description copied from interface: Layer
Destroys this layer, removing it from its parent layer. Any resources associated with this layer are freed, and it cannot be reused after being destroyed. Destroying a layer that has children will destroy them as well.

Specified by:
destroy in interface Layer

public boolean destroyed()
Description copied from interface: Layer
Whether this layer has been destroyed. If true, the layer can no longer be used.

setVisible in interface Layer

interactive

public boolean interactive()
Description copied from interface: Layer
Returns true if this layer reacts to clicks and touches. If a layer is interactive, it will respond to Layer.hitTest(pythagoras.f.Point), which forms the basis for the click and touch processing provided by Pointer#addListener, Touch#addListener and Mouse#addListener.

Specified by:
interactive in interface Layer

setInteractive

public void setInteractive(boolean interactive)
Description copied from interface: Layer
Configures this layer as reactive to clicks and touches, or not. Note that a layer's interactivity is automatically activated when a listener is added to the layer (or to a child of a GroupLayer) via Pointer#addListener, etc. Also a GroupLayer will be made non-interactive automatically if an event is dispatched to it and it discovers that it has no interactive children. Manual management of interactivity is thus generally only useful for "leaf" nodes in the scene graph.

Specified by:
setInteractive in interface Layer

alpha

public float alpha()
Description copied from interface: Layer
Return the global alpha value for this layer.

The global alpha value for a layer controls the opacity of the layer but does not affect the current drawing operation. I.e., when Game.paint(float) is called and the Layer is drawn, this alpha value is applied to the alpha channel of the Layer.

By default, the alpha for a Layer is 1.0 (not transparent).

Specified by:
alpha in interface Layer
Returns:
alpha in range [0,1] where 0 is transparent and 1 is opaque

setAlpha

public void setAlpha(float alpha)
Description copied from interface: Layer
Set the global alpha value for this layer.

The global alpha value for a layer controls the opacity of the layer but does not affect the current drawing operation. I.e., when Game.paint(float) is called and the Layer is drawn, this alpha value is applied to the alpha channel of the Layer.

Values outside the range [0,1] will be clamped to the range [0,1].

Specified by:
setAlpha in interface Layer
Parameters:
alpha - alpha value in range [0,1] where 0 is transparent and 1 is opaque

setScale

public void setScale(float s)
Description copied from interface: Layer
Sets the scale of the layer.

This sets the scale of the layer's transformation matrix so coordinates in the layer will be multiplied by this scale.

Note that a scale of 1 is equivalent to no scale.

Specified by:

hitTest

public Layer hitTest(pythagoras.f.Point p)
Description copied from interface: Layer
Tests whether the supplied (layer relative) point "hits" this layer or any of its children. By default a hit is any point that falls in a layer's bounding box. A group layer checks its children for hits.

Note that this method mutates the supplied point. If a layer is hit, the point will contain the original point as translated into that layer's coordinate system. If no layer is hit, the point will be changed to an undefined value.

Specified by:
hitTest in interface Layer
Returns:
this layer if it was the hit layer, a child of this layer if a child of this layer was hit, or null if neither this layer, nor its children were hit.

hitTestDefault

public Layer hitTestDefault(pythagoras.f.Point p)
Description copied from interface: Layer
Like Layer.hitTest(pythagoras.f.Point) except that it ignores a configured Layer.HitTester. This allows one to configure a hit tester which checks custom properties and then falls back on the default hit testing implementation.

Specified by:
hitTestDefault in interface Layer

Description copied from interface: Layer
Configures a custom hit tester for this layer. May also be called with null to clear out any custom hit tester.

addListener

public Connection addListener(Pointer.Listener listener)
Description copied from interface: Layer
Registers a listener with this layer that will be notified if a click/touch event happens within its bounds. Events dispatched to this listener will have their Event#localX and Event#localY values set to the coordinates of the click/touch as transformed into this layer's coordinate system. Event#x and Event#y will always contain the screen (global) coordinates of the click/touch.

When a listener is added, the layer and all of its parents are marked as interactive. Interactive layers intercept touches/clicks. When all listeners are disconnected (including Mouse and Touch listeners), the layer will be marked non-interactive. Its parents are lazily marked non-interactive as it is discovered that they have no interactive children. Thus if you require that a layer continue to intercept click/touch events to prevent them from being dispatched to layers "below" it, you must register a NOOP listener on the layer, or manually call Layer.setInteractive(boolean) after removing the last listener.

Specified by:
addListener in interface Layer

addListener

public Connection addListener(Mouse.Listener listener)
Description copied from interface: Layer
Registers a listener with this layer that will be notified if a mouse event happens within its bounds. Events dispatched to this listener will have their Event#localX and Event#localY values set to the coordinates of the mouse as transformed into this layer's coordinate system. Event#x and Event#y will always contain the screen (global) coordinates of the mouse.

Note that mouse wheel events are not dispatched, as they lack coordinates. If a game wishes to determine the layer over which the mouse is hovering when wheel events are dispatched, it can register a global mouse-movement handler to track the position of the mouse, and use the latest position to determine which layer is under the mouse at the time of wheeling.

When a listener is added, the layer and all of its parents are marked as interactive. Interactive layers intercept mice events. When all listeners are disconnected (including Pointer and Touch listeners), the layer will be marked non-interactive. Its parents are lazily marked non-interactive as it is discovered that they have no interactive children. Thus if you require that a layer continue to intercept mouse events to prevent them from being dispatched to layers "below" it, you must register a NOOP listener on the layer, or manually call Layer.setInteractive(boolean) after removing the last listener.

Specified by:
addListener in interface Layer
